reviewText: Record labels, please look at this set. A blu-ray with a number of different listening options (including demos) as well as a CD in the set. This is how ALL albums should be released now, not just reissues.Such a better deal than the recent UME "pure blu-ray audio" releases that have largely stuck with stereo releases, even when a 5.1 mix was available (e.g., Layla).This is a magnificent set.
summary: Great example of how these sets should be released

reviewText: Well done Mr. Wilson. Surround mix is beautiful! Only bummer is no extra goodies, besides one extra song on the DVD-A (previously on "Coat of Many Cupboards" box only)."Skylarking" next; PLEASE.

reviewText: XTC - Nonsuch (1992)XTC started life as an arty New Wave band. Gradually a softer, syrupy, sometimes saccharine side of XTC developed, culminating in the brilliant, SERGENT PEPPER-esque SKYLARKING. The following album, ORANGES AND LEMONS, dove deeper into the psychedelic well with mixed results. NONSUCH followed, and at 17 tracks could be considered a double album like its predecessor. That saccharine side is fully indulged here, but as far as baroque pop goes, this is really tops. So it's really just a question of taste as to whether or not you will like this album. And, with few exceptions, it offends my sensibilities; I can hardly stand it."The Ballad of Peter Pumpkinhead" kicks things off with an infectious big beat and a rockin' pop song. Unfortunately, nothing on the rest of the album rocks like this. Some people who heard the single or saw the video (which got tons of play on MTV) and bought the album felt duped by this bait and switch. Not cool.Quite frankly, the rest of the album is just too twee, sing-songy and downright wimpy for my tastes. There's undoubtedly some very good pop music on here if you like sweet, super-melodic songs that border on precious and sound like they belong on Sesame Street. One exception is the dreamy "The Ugly Underneath" which does bring back the big drums for at least part of the song. There are snippets of songs that I enjoy, but they're usually ruined by some mushy, cloying melody with lyrics to match. XTC even get preachy on a few songs ("The Smartest Monkeys," "Books Are Burning," "War Dance") and that's not much of a turn-on either. I got this album back when it came out and I never listen to it (although I'll listen to "Peter Pumpkinhead" if it comes on). No doubt there are many XTC fans out there who would poo-poo all over my review, but what with the rampant wimpiness, the preaching, and the bait and switch, I just can't rate NONSUCH any higher than two stars. Although technically very good music, most of it just turns my stomach.rating: not recommended

reviewText: Nonsuch may not have been the greatest CD that XTC put out, but when you include the bonus material and the number of mixes that you can listen to, this is fantastic. This is how bands should re-issue their recordings.
Title: N/A

reviewText: All I can say about this excellent work is THANK YOU ANDY PARTRIDGE & STEVEN WILSON!!! A masterpiece of modern music that has finally gotten it's due!! Worth every penny!!! Also want to remind fans of XTC that guitarist Dave Gregory is currently working with Big Big Train and Tin Spirits creating more work of exceptional, high-quality musical art. If you haven't checked out these bands, do so NOW!! You won't be sorry! AND I also want everyone to know that I recently read online that Steven Wilson has said that he will probably be remixing more of XTC's catalog!!! I can barely WAIT!! This is just FANTASTIC NEWS!!!

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: Cult band XTC finally broke through in the U.S. with the cult hit single "Dear God" (they had almost broken through with their previous MTV staple "Senses Working Overtime") and, hoping to built on that success released a series of strong albums in rapid succession with singles that also had high profile singles for the band ("Mayor Simpleton", "King for a Day") which leads us to the band's last album before their "strike" (for those that don't know the band went on strike and refused to record until Virgin records modified their recording contract with fairer terms or until their contract ran out) "Nonsuch" which uses a similiarly template to the strong "Skylarking".Produced by the late Gus Dudgeon (Elton John, David Bowie), the band were never exactly thrilled with the final version so when Partridge decided to release a high definition version he asked Porcupine Tree's Steve Wilson to do a remix of the album. The remix on the CD sounds good but I could have done without the use of limiting on the CD. The CD here isn't quite as dynamic as the original but is better than the 2001 reissue.Be aware that, unlike the original CD and vinyl, this version does not have the cross fades between tracks. There is also some limiting applied which impacts the dynamics on the CD somewhat. This was encouraged by Wilson (perhaps keeping in mind that many fans rip CDs to their hard drive or play item back on iPods, iPhones and devices like Squeezebox. Without the cross fades, it's a much cleaner break for those listening on playlists or randomly) so if you like the cross fades you may want to keep your earlier edition.As a bonus the CD includes the track "Didn't Hurt a Bit" which was abandoned when the band couldn't work out a finished arrangement they were pleased with and which Partridge and Moulding finished later for inclusion on "A Coat of Many Cupboards". It's a nice bonus track to have and a terrific song from Moulding that fits the feel of the album (it's placed at the end of the CD).Likewise, the 5.1 lossless remix for the blu-ray sounds marvelous but in a different way--the different discrete channels creates the impression you are IN the studio with the band.Home demos for many of the tracks are included on the blu-ray from Andy Partridge and Colin Moulding's archives. Some of the home demos for both appeared on various single releases as well as the "A Coat of Many Cupboards" boxed set previously released. Having said that, there are also excerpts from the various work tapes included here that have never been released before providing a progressive look at the development of the songs.The list of demo/worktapes:Always Winter, Never Christmas [Andy's home demo)(previously released as a CD single bonus track)Books Are Burning [Andy's Home Demo](previously unreleased)Goosey Goosey [Andy's Home Demo](Previously released as part of "Fuzzy Warbles")Wrapped In Grey [Andy's Home Demo](previously unreleased)That Wave [Andy's Home Demo](previously unreleased)Goodbye Humanosaurus [Andy's Home Demo](previously released as part of "Fuzzy Warbles")Dear Madam Barnum [Andy's Home Demo](previously released)Crocodile [Andy's Home Demo](previously released as part of "Fuzzy Warbles")Difficult Age [Andy's Home Demo](previously released as part of "Fuzzy Warbles")The Ugly Underneath [Andy's Home Demo](previously unreleased)Holly Up On Poppy [Andy's Home Demo](previously released as part of "Fuzzy Warbles")The Ballad of Peter Pumpkinhead [Andy's Home Demo](Previously released as part of "Fuzzy Warbles")Then She Appeared [Andy's Home Demo](Previously unreleased)It's Snowing Angels [Andy's Home Demo](previously released as part of "Fuzzy Warbles")Rook [Andy's Home Demo](previously unreleased)Humble Daisy [Andy's Home Demo](Previously released on "Fuzzy Warbles")Rip Van Reuben [Andy's Home Demo](previously released as part of "Fuzzy Warbles"(I'm the Man Who Murdered Love [Andy's Home Demo](Previously released as a CD single bonus track)Omnibus [Andy's Home Demo](Previously released as a CD bonus track)The Disappointed [First Reference Recording](previously unreleased)The Disappointed [Second Reference Recording](previously unreleased)The Disappointed [Andy's Home Demo](previously released on "Fuzzy Warbles")Wonder Annual [Andy's Home Demo](previously released on "Fuzzy Warbles")My Bird Performs [Colin's Work Tapes](Previously released as a CD single bonus track)Didn't Hurt a Bit [Colin's Work Tapes](released as a bonus track on Japanese "Homespun" CD as a bonus track)The Smartest Monkeys [Colin's Work Tapes](released as a CD single bonus track)Down a Peg [Colin's Work Tapes](released as a CD single bonus track)Bungalow [Colin's Work Tapes](released as a CD single bonus track)War Dance [Colin's Work Tapes](released as a CD single bonus track)Car Out of Control [Colin's Work Tapes](Previously unreleased)Where Did the Ordinary People Go? [Colin's Work Tapes] (Previously unreleased)We also get stereo high rez versions of the remixes.We also get instrumental remixes of the various tracks, footage of the band working on the album shot by Didgeon (its in SD and about 45 minutes documenting work on "Then She Appeared," " The Disappointed" and "It Didn't Hurt A Bit" which shows a slightly different arrangement for the latter song)and promotional videos made for "The Mayor of Simpleton" and "The Disappointed".We also get an excellent booklet with new essays written by Partridge, Moulding and guitarist/keyboardist Dave Gregory about the making of the album, their thoughts on the songs and their reaction to the recording twenty years later.If you're a fan of the band this is an excellent remix/remaster and worth picking up. I haven't heard the DVD-A version (that doesn't have the videos from what I understand) but I'm sure it's equally fine. This deluxe edition is exceptionally done and kudos to Andy Partridge (who supervised the remix and packaging) and Steve Wilson (who did the actualy work on the tapes and remixes).Highly recommended.
summary: Remixed, remodeled and presented in both ster has never sounded better (on Blu, the CD has some limiting applied)
